summary: An FBI Miami Division request to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) for scanning and processing telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager. The records are from an address book Rodriguez possessed, believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He possessed an address book with names and numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the individual whose former house manager, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed an address book believed to contain contact information for Epstein's underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Alfredo Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, for attempting to sell an address book believed to contain victim information.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records collection
events.description: Telephone records generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (circa 2010) are prioritized for processing in the investigation.

locations: Winchester, Virginia (Location of FBI DocLab at 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was under FBI investigation for obstruction of justice for attempting to sell an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.
The FBI was processing telephone records from the address book, targeting the number 340-690-1012, to load into the Telephone Application (TA) database for investigative use.
The document reveals an internal FBI process (Baleen Sweep) for scanning, automating, and analyzing large volumes of documentary evidence, including telephone records, to support investigations.
The address book and its contents were evidence that Rodriguez failed to turn over in response to federal subpoenas issued during pending civil litigation against Epstein.
